title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of people around the world who have been forced to leave their homes to escape war, violence, and persecution?
According to the UN's 1951 Convention relating to the status of refugees, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to economic reasons.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to well-founded fears of being persecuted.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is inside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home due to conflict and violence.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is a migrant and has left their country for better economic opportunities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the terms "migrant" and "refugee"?

options.label: A
options.text: A migrant is someone who has left their country for economic reasons, while a refugee is someone who has left their country due to persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: A migrant is someone who has left their country due to persecution, while a refugee is someone who has left their country for economic reasons.

options.label: C
options.text: A migrant is someone who has left their country for better economic opportunities, while a refugee is someone who has left their country due to conflict and violence.

options.label: D
options.text: A migrant is someone who has left their country for conflict and violence, while a refugee is someone who has left their country for better economic opportunities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why many refugees are unable to travel by standard routes?

options.label: D
options.text: Limited access to shelter, water, or food

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a refugee camp?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide long-term shelter and integration options for refugees

options.label: B
options.text: To provide short-term shelter until inhabitants can safely return home or be integrated into the host country

options.label: C
options.text: To provide resettlement options for refugees

options.label: D
options.text: To provide education and job opportunities for refugees

multiple-choice.question: What is the first legal step for a displaced person in a new country?

options.label: B
options.text: To be recognized as a refugee

options.label: D
options.text: To be integrated into the host country

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle that prevents a nation from sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened?
What is the main obligation of host countries towards people they have recognized as refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide long-term shelter and integration options

options.label: B
options.text: To guarantee a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination

options.label: C
options.text: To provide education and job opportunities

options.label: D
options.text: To resettle refugees in another country

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why many refugee children are out of school?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of funding for education programs

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of remembering the stories of refugees who are currently displaced?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the reasons why they are displaced

title: Can wildlife adapt to climate change? - Erin Eastwood

options.label: B

options.label: A
options.text: To blend in with the snowy backdrop

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following species has adapted to warmer waters by spawning earlier in the season?

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's spine in a zero G environment?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes shorter and more compressed.

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same as on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: Every vertebrae has a chance to move up, giving the person extra height.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of gravity on a person's spine?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the spine to elongate.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the spine to compress.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the spine.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why astronauts wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their eyes are sensitive to light.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their vision changes due to changes in intracranial pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need to correct for nearsightedness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of running on a treadmill in space?

options.label: A
options.text: To get exercise and stay healthy.

options.label: B
options.text: To give loads into the bones to keep them from atrophying.

options.label: C
options.text: To simulate the effects of gravity.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's bones in a zero G environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They become stronger and more dense.

options.label: B
options.text: They change shape and lose calcium, becoming more brittle.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same as on Earth.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the heart change shape in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's pumping harder to pull blood up from the feet.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's pumping easier due to the lack of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's not having to pump as hard to pull blood up from the feet.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the effects of a zero G environment on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the body to become taller.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the body to become shorter.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes the body to remain the same as on Earth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of wearing glasses in space?

options.label: C
options.text: To correct for changes in vision due to intracranial pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's intracranial pressure in space?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains the same as on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: It changes due to pushes on the eyeball.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases due to the lack of gravity.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it worth exploring space despite the effects on the body?

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the spirit of exploration.
